content.description: Sit start with a good but high and hard to reach right-hand undercling and a small lefthand undercling crimp on the overhang. Pull on with difficulty and move up to some sloping rails and climb the face and the arete with friction and balance dependent moves. Stand tall and trust the feet in order to reach the sloping lip. Topout with care using a good righthand crystal and slopers for the left.
content.location: This problem is the first arete visible on the tall boulder.

content.description: Stand start with a right hand Sloper on the bulge, and a lefthand sidepull in a vertical crack. Pull onto the wall with some feet on the overhang and punch up to an edge found above the left hand in the vertical crack. Once here, figure out a way to smack up to a seam on the slab, then somehow match and do a tricky and difficult mantle.
content.location: This problem is found to the left of "Optimus" on the steep overhang. Right hand starts on the bulge, lefthand on a sloping sidepull in the vertical crack.

content.description: Sit start with a good righthand and lefthand matched or on a sloping underclingÂ out left. Figure out the feet and pull up to some crystal sidepulls and gastons before reaching out to the unique pocket feature. From here pull up to the sloping lip and throw it behind you.
content.protection: 1 or 2 pads. There is a rock that could be hazardous if a punt on the topout unfolds.

content.description: This is a large secluded boulder that is rarely visited by many Blair-going climbers. This boulder holds a few classic lines and one or two not so classic lines. After the recent timber harvest, this boulder now proudly overlooks a large clearing, making the gem of the boulder "Optimus" that much more proud and airy.
